{{linkrot|date=September 2011}} {{Use British English|date=July 2011}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2011}} [[File:Got Talent Series Map.png|thumb|Location of different franchises of ''Got Talent''
{{legend|#502CC8|Own version}}{{legend|#54AEFD|Joint version}}]] The '''''Got Talent'' franchise''' is a British [[TV format]] conceived and owned by [[Simon Cowell]]'s [[Syco#Syco TV|SYCOtv]] company. A pilot show was made in Britain, hosted by [[Paul O'Grady]], but after O'Grady's split with [[ITV]], the series was postponed, resulting in ''[[America's Got Talent]]'' - the first full series of the format. It has spawned [[Spin-off (media)|spin-offs]] in 39 countries, in what is now referred to as the ''Got Talent'' format, similar to that described by [[FremantleMedia]] of the [[Idol series|Idol format]].{{fact|date=October 2011}} The ''Got Talent'' franchise is one of the fastest growing international franchises, closing the gap on other successful franchises such as ''[[The Weakest Link]]'',''[[The X Factor (TV series)|The X Factor]]'', ''[[List of national variants in Who Wants to Be a Millionaire?|Who Wants to Be a Millionaire?]]'', ''[[Dancing with the Stars]]'' and ''[[Idol Series|Idol]]'' franchises, all of which also originated in the [[United Kingdom]].{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/4436837.stm | work=BBC News | title=Millionaire dominates global TV | date=12 April 2005 | accessdate=4 May 2010}} ==Original series== {{see also|America's Got Talent|Britain's Got Talent}} The ''Got Talent'' franchise was a British invention, with comedian and talk show host [[Paul O'Grady]] producing a pilot for [[ITV]]. O'Grady left the network after disputes with ITV, resulting in [[Simon Cowell]], creator of the show, moving the concept to America while he and ITV searched for a new show host. Due to these issues, the ''Got Talent'' franchise ended up debuting first on the [[NBC]] network in the [[United States]] on 21 June 2006, with judges [[David Hasselhoff]], [[Brandy Norwood]], and [[Piers Morgan]]. The show's original series was hosted by [[Regis Philbin]]. Most recently, the judging panel consists of [[Howie Mandel]], [[Sharon Osbourne]], along with Morgan, and is hosted by [[Nick Cannon]]. The grand prize on ''America's Got Talent'' is $1 million, and, since season 3, a chance to headline a show on the [[Las Vegas Strip]]. ''America's Got Talent'' proved extremely successful for NBC, pulling in high ratings in both total viewers and the younger 18-49 demographic. The show's initial success in America is credited with the eventual launch of the British series, and the overall global launch of the ''Got Talent'' franchise. ITV eventually debuted ''[[Britain's Got Talent]]'' on 9 June 2007 with Cowell, Morgan and [[Amanda Holden]] as judges, and [[Ant & Dec]] as hosts of the show. Morgan stepped down after series 4 due to commitments hosting ''[[Piers Morgan Tonight]]'' on [[CNN]]. For series 5, Cowell only attended the live shows as he was busy launching ''[[The X Factor (U.S.)|The X Factor]]'' in America, so [[Michael McIntyre]] and [[David Hasselhoff]] joined the panel with Holden. A third season started on 23 October 2010. ===Australia=== {{see|Australia's Got Talent}} In February 2007, ''[[Australia's Got Talent]]'' debuted on [[Seven Network]].{{cite web|url=http://www.australiasgottalent.com.au |title=Australia's Got Talent |publisher=Australia's Got Talent |date= |accessdate=9 May 2010}} [[Grant Denyer]] is the host, with [[Dannii Minogue]], [[Red Symons]] and [[Tom Burlinson]] judging the performances. On the fifth season, [[SmaÃ¯n]] was replaced by the singer [[Dave]]. ===Georgia=== {{see|Georgia's Got Talent!}} ===Germany=== {{see|Das Supertalent}} For the new season 2007/2008 [[RTL Television]], one of the main German TV stations, announced ''[[:de:Das Supertalent|Das Supertalent]]'' (''The Supertalent''). The show went on a break for the 2008 season, returning only on 10 October 2009 with a new line-up of judges. ===India=== {{see|India's Got Talent}} The Indian version of the show called ''[[India's Got Talent]]'' started in Mid 2009 on India's hit TV Channel [[Colors (India TV channel)|Colors]]. This show has ended their episodes on 26 December 2010 with Vania Larissa, 15 y.o Opera Singer is the winner. ===Italy=== {{see|Italia's Got Talent}} The Italian version of the show called ''Italia's Got Talent'' is airing on [[Canale 5]] between 12 December 2009 and 17 May 2010.It is hosted by [[Simone Annichiarico]] and [[Geppi Cucciari]]. [[Gerry Scotti]], [[Maria De Filippi]] and [[Rudy Zerbi]]. ===Netherlands=== A Dutch version called ''[[:nl:Holland's Got Talent|Holland's Got Talent]]'', started on [[SBS 6]] during 2008. [[New Zealand's Got Talent]]. [[Paul Ellis]] (who also judges [[NZ Idol]]), The judges are [[Miriama Smith]] (actress and participant from [[Dancing with the Stars (New Zealand TV series)|Dancing with the Stars]]) and Richard Driver (the host of Radio with Pictures) [[Andrew Mulligan]] (the host of ''[[The Crowd Goes Wild]]'') and [[Jason Reeves (radio broadcaster)|Jason Reeves]] (radio host of ''[[Classic Hits FM]]'') are the hosts. TMC (That Mean Crew) - also a dance act, were the runner ups. ===Norway=== {{see|Norske Talenter}} [[TV 2 (Norway)|TV 2]]'s version is ''Norske Talenter'' (''Norwegian Talents''). The [[Norske Talenter (series 2)|second season]] which began airing on 13 February 2009, saw [[Pia Lykke]] replace Stokstad as host and male hip hop dance quartet [[Quick (dance group)|Quick]] won the grand prize. ===Philippines=== {{see|Pilipinas Got Talent}} [[ABS-CBN]] franchised the Philippine version of the international talent show series "Got Talent"{{cite web|url=http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/entertainment/10/05/09/abs-cbn-bags-%E2%80%98got-talent%E2%80%99-franchise |title=ABS-CBN bags 'Got Talent' franchise |publisher=ABS-CBN News Online |date=10 May 2009 |first=Reyma |last=Buan-Deveza |accessdate=9 May 2010}} and called "[[Pilipinas Got Talent]]".{{cite web|url=http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/entertainment/10/05/09/abs-cbn-bags-%E2%80%98got-talent%E2%80%99-franchise |title=ABS-CBN bags âGot Talentâ franchise |publisher=ABS-CBN News Online |date= |first=Reyma |last=Buan-Deveza |accessdate=9 May 2010}} Hosted by [[Luis Manzano]] and [[Billy Joe Crawford]]. [[Pilipinas Got Talent (season 2)|Season 2]] started to air on 26 February 2011. Marcelito Pomoy was crowned winner of his talent of singing with a female voice. [[Pilipinas Got Talent (season 3)|Season 3]] began airing on 9 July 2011. The up coming season that was promised was the [[Pilipinas Got Talent (season 4)|Season 4]]. ===Poland=== {{see|Mam talent!}} The Polish version of the show is called ''[[:pl:Mam talent!|Mam Talent!]]'' (''I've Got Talent!'') and premiered on 13 September 2008 on [[TVN (Poland)|TVN]]. The prize has grown to 10,000,000 rubles (~315,000$). ===Romania=== The Romanian version of the show, ''RomÃ¢nii au talent'' (''[[Romania's Got Talent|Romanians got talent]]''), premiered on [[Pro TV]] on 18 February 2011 and is hosted by Smiley (local singer) and Pavel BartoÈ (local actor). The judges are Andra (singer and TV hostess), Andi Moisescu (TV producer and presenter) and Mihai Petre (dancer, choreographer, actor and jury member of the local version of ''[[Dancing with the stars#Romania|Dancing with the stars]]''). The top prize of â¬120,000 was won by Adrian Tutu, a young rapper. ===Serbia=== {{see|Ja imam talenat}} The Serbian version of the show is called ''Ja imam talenat!'' (''I've Got Talent!''). The hosts are [[Ivana BajiÄ]] and [[Vladimir AleksiÄ]] while the jury members are: conductor of the Belgrade Philharmonic Orchestra and pianist - [[Ivan Tasovac]], composer and music producer - [[Aleksandar MiliÄ Mili]] and finally, theater and television actress [[Danica MaksimoviÄ]].
The first season began in September 2009, and was broadcast on [[RTV Pink]]. The show was won by a trio of music players: [[violin|violinists]] Darko and Sandra Piler and [[accordion]] player Danijel Piler. The second season was broadcast by Serbian public broadcaster, [[Radio Television of Serbia|RTS]], and started in April 2011.{{cite news| url=http://www.24sata.rs/show.php?id=92730 | publisher=24 Sata | title=Ja imam talenat od 17. aprila | language=Serbian | accessdate=5 April 2011}} Winners of the second series are two [[deaf]] dancers: Milica and Nenad. The date of the auditions for the third series are yet to be announced. ===Slovakia=== The Slovakian version called ''[[:sk:Slovensko mÃ¡ talent|Slovensko mÃ¡ Talent]]''http://talent.markiza.sk (''Slovakia's Got Talent'') began on [[MarkÃ­za]] on 21 September 2008. [[MaroÅ¡ KramÃ¡r]] and [[Barbora RakovskÃ¡]] were the hosts of the show. The jury consisted of [[Jan Kraus]] (Czech comedian and actor), [[Adela BanÃ¡Å¡ovÃ¡]] (Slovakian radio and TV moderator, and host of ''[[Slovensko hÄ¾adÃ¡ SuperStar]]''), and [[Palo Habera]] (who was also one of the judges on ''[[Slovensko hÄ¾adÃ¡ SuperStar]]'' and is leader of the rock band TEAM). Announced on 8 December, the winner of â¬100,000 (3 million Slovakian crowns) was [[The Old School Brothers]], who were actually a group of 5 boys and a girl. Slovakia is the first country with a group winning the competition. ===Slovenia=== The Slovenian version called ''[[:sl:Slovenija ima talent|Slovenija ima talent]] (''Slovenia's Got Talent''), has begun on [[POP TV]] in Spring 2010. The auditions will begin on 16 January in ten biggest cities in the country. The producers of the show will choose the best talents of all and give them the chance to try out in the show for the title of the first most talented Slovenian. The judges are [[Brane Kastelic]], [[Lucienne LonÄina]] and [[Branko ÄakarmiÅ¡]], Hosts are [[Vid ValiÄ]] and [[Peter Poles]]. Lina KuduzoviÄ, a 7-year-old singer won the competition with a cover of "The Power of Love" from Jennifer Page. [[Maja Keuc]], who was second, won the national selection for Eurovision song contest 2011 and will present Slovenia in Germany with song "No one". More on [http://talent.24ur.com/] ===South Africa=== {{see|SA's Got Talent}} The South African version of the show is called ''SA's Got Talent'' and started on 1 October 2009. The three judges who will be putting contestants through their paces are veteran radio and media personality [[Shado Twala]], ''[[Idols (South Africa)|Idols]]'' judge [[Randall Abrahams]], and [[Ian von Memerty]], of ''[[Strictly Come Dancing (South Africa)|Strictly Come Dancing]]'' fame. The hosts are radio personalities, [[Rob van Vuuren]] and [[Anele Mdoda]]. The top prize money is [[South African rand|R]]250,000. ===South Korea=== {{see|Korea's Got Talent}} ''Korea's Got Talent'' premiered on 4 July 2011 on [[tvN Asia]].http://www.chtvn.com/VR/gottalent/ It was won by dancer Joo Ming-Jong. ===Spain=== [[Cuatro (channel)|Cuatro]] in Spain picked up the rights to the ''[[:es:Tienes Talento|Tienes Talento]]'' (''You Have Talent'') format. It premiered on 25 January 2008, in Primetime.{{cite web|author=By |url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117974803.html?categoryid=14&cs=1 |title=Cuatro's got 'Talent' |publisher=Variety |date=26 October 2007 |first=John |last=Hopewell |accessdate=9 May 2010}} It was hosted by [[Nuria Roca]] (who also hosted [[Factor X (Spain)|Factor X]]) and [[Eduardo AldÃ¡n]] (actor and TV host) and the judges were [[Natalia MillÃ¡n]] (actress, singer & dancer), [[Miqui Puig]] (singer, DJ and judge also on Factor X) and [[Josep Vicent]] (Artistic director, specialized in musical creations and performances). The top prize of [[Euro|â¬]]150,000 was won by 16-year-old [[flamenco]] singer [[Salva Rodriguez]]. Controversially, Telecinco launched a near-identical show called ''[[:es:TÃº sÃ­ que vales|TÃº sÃ­ que vales]]'' ('You're worth it'), sparking a war of words between the two stations. It remains unclear whether Cuatro, who own the rights to the official format in Spain, will take legal action. ===Sweden=== {{see|Talang (TV show)}} The Swedish version called ''Talang 2007'' (''Talent 2007'') aired on [[TV4 (Sweden)|TV4]]. The host was [[Peppe Eng]]. The jury was [[Bert Karlsson]], [[Hanna Hedlund]] and [[Tobbe Blom]]. The prize 1,000,000 [[Swedish kronor]] (Jul 2007, approximately Â£73,000; US$148,000; A$174,000) was won by [[Zillah & Totte]] featuring 18-year-old [[ventriloquist]] Cecilia AndrÃ©n and her puppet monkey Totte. ''[[Talang 2008]]'' was won by the 10-year-old singer [[Zara Larsson]] . [[Sofia Wistam]] replaced Hanna Hedlund as the female judge and [[Kodjo Akolor]] became Peppe Eng's sidekick. ''[[Talang 2009]]'' saw Tobbe Blom move from judging duties to hosting duties. He hosted alongside Swedish-Finnish multi-platinum selling recording artist, singer, musician, songwriter, actor, and comedian [[Markoolio]]. [[Eurovision Song Contest 1999]] winner [[Charlotte Perrelli]] replaced Sofia Wistam as the female judge and [[Johan PrÃ¥mell]] replaced Blom as one of the two male judges. It started airing on 3 April with 30-year-old magician [[Charlie Caper]] winning series 3 with 12-year-old pianist [[David Movsesian]] as the runner up. Caper is the first magician anywhere to win. ===Switzerland=== ''[[:de:Die grÃ¶ssten Schweizer Talente|Die grÃ¶ssten Schweizer Talente]]'' (Switzerland's Biggest Talent) premiered on 29 January 2011 on German-speaking channel [[Schweizer Fernsehen|SF1]]. The show is hosted by [[Sven Epiney]] and [[Andrea Jansen]]. The judges are [[DJ Bobo]] (singer), [[Christa Rigozzi]] (former Miss Switzerland) and Roman Kilchsperger. ===Thailand=== {{see|Thailand's Got Talent}} Thailand's Got Talent premiered on 6 March 2011 on [[Channel 3 (Thailand)|channel 3]] and is the fifth country in Asia to license the show. The three judges Nirut Sirijanya, Benz Pomchita Na Songkla, and Pinyo Rutham join hosts Krit Sriphumset and Nake-Ketusepswasdi Palakwong na Ayudhaya. ===Ukraine=== [[:uk:Ð£ÐºÑÐ°ÑÐ½Ð° Ð¼Ð°Ñ ÑÐ°Ð»Ð°Ð½Ñ|Ð£ÐºÑÐ°ÑÐ½Ð° Ð¼Ð°Ñ ÑÐ°Ð»Ð°Ð½Ñ]] (Ukraine's Got Talent) premiered on 3 April 2009 on [[STB (Channel)|STB]]. The three judges are [[Vlad Yama]] (Ukrainian dancer), [[Slava Frolova]] (showmaker and businesslady, also owner of trademark "ÐÑÐ±ÑÐ·"/"Watermellon"), and [[Igor Kondratyuk]] (scientist, showman and producer ). The prize of 1,000,000 [[Ukrainian hryvnia]] (April 2009, approximately US$125,000) was won by 25-year-old [[sand animation]] artist [[Kseniya Simonova]], and 26-year-old songstress Olena Kovtun in second season. Official Ukraine got talent YouTube / http://www.youtube.com/user/TheApexStar ===United Kingdom=== {{see|Britain's Got Talent}} Britain's Got Talent is a British television talent show competition which started in June 2007. The show is produced by FremantleMedia's TalkbackThames and Simon Cowell's production company SYCOtv. The show is broadcast on ITV in Britain and TV3 in Ireland. The spin-off show Britain's Got More Talent is shown in both countries also. Anyone of age with some sort of talent to audition for the show can audition (singers, dancers, comedians, variety acts, etc). Acts will compete against each other in order to gain the audience support while trying to win the title of "Winner of Britain's Got Talent". ===United States=== {{see|America's Got Talent}} In June 2006, ''[[America's Got Talent]]'' debuted on [[NBC]]. The [[America's Got Talent (season 1)|first season]] was hosted by [[Regis Philbin]], and had [[Piers Morgan]], [[Brandy Norwood]] and [[David Hasselhoff]] on the panel. Since then, Norwood and Hasselhoff have both stepped down, with [[Sharon Osbourne]] and [[Howie Mandel]] replacing both on the panel, respectively. After Philbin stepped down after 2006, [[Jerry Springer]] hosted the show from 2007 to 2008. [[Nick Cannon]] has been hosting the show since 2009. The American version's grand prize is $1 million, and, since Season 3, a chance to headline a show on the [[Las Vegas Strip]]. A Spanish language version entitled Tengo Talento, Mucho Talento (I Have Talent, Much Talent) was started in 2010 on Estrella TV. == World== {{see|World's Got Talent}} '''[[World's Got Talent]]''' is an upcoming talent television show that puts 25 winners from various Got Talent series to compete against each other. From there, one of them will be crowned the winner of The World's greatest Talent and take home a million dollar prize. The series will be hosted by [[Piers Morgan]], who is a judge on both the American and UK series. The screening date is currently unknown. It is launched by [[Simon Cowell]]. There will be six judges (three male and three female) on the ''World's Got Talent'' judging panel; two each respectively from the [[America's Got Talent|American]], [[Australia's Got Talent|Australian]] and [[Britain's Got Talent|British]] versions of the series. *[[Howie Mandel]] (from American series) *[[Sharon Osbourne]] (from American series) *[[Brian McFadden]] (from Australian series) *[[Dannii Minogue]] (from Australian series) *[[Amanda Holden]] (from UK series) *[[Simon Cowell]] (from UK series) == Other countries == ; [[Austria]]: [[ATV (Austria)|ATV]] aired ''[[:de:It's Showtime|It's Showtime]]'' hosted by [[Alex Scheurer]] and the judges are [[Toni Polster]], the runner up of [[Dancing Stars]], [[Gregor Bloeb]] and [[Simone Stelzer]].
